content.description:
This is an interesting friction route that will remind you of Stone Mountain. It follows a very shallow water groove. The climb "Tennessee Mare" is just to the left with its first bolt at 20 feet up and only two more after that.

Depending on how you top out, this route can be a real rope stretcher.
content.protection: There are 3 well-spaced bolts. The first bolt is around 15-20 feet up with some very thin moves to access it. The last bolt is at least 50 feet below any opportunities for anchors. Top belay options include bolts at the bottom and to climbers left of Camptown Races (Start angling to the right when leaving the water groove to reach these). There are another pair of bolts around 50 feet climbers left (angle left when leaving the water groove), or you can go straight up and thrash through undergrowth below the High Plains Drifter ledge.
content.location:
This climb is located on the wall below and to the left of the start of Camptown Races. When rapping in from the anchors at the base of Camptown races you should angle to your left to get to the start of Tennessee Stud--and to avoid a bushwacky landing.

The rappel takes two 60 meter ropes. One 70 meter might work if you're careful.

content.description: This route begins at the base of Camptown Races and follows a mostly vegetated ledge for a full rope length until you are above a tree island in the Dodge City area. It is an easier alternative to get across the cliff rather than the bush whacking along the base. You can also start the travers from the first or second bolts on Camptown Races to reduce rope drag, which bumps the rating up into the 5.4-5.5 range.
content.protection: There is room for a piece or two.  The climbing is easy, but a slip could result in a very long fall.

content.description: A good introduction to friction. The crux is the steeper section at the bottom, though the lichen at the top can also get your attention.
content.protection: There are four well-spaced bolts with a long runout on easier ground near the top. The top also has two three bolt anchors--one about ten feet above the other. When rapping in be sure to know the end of your rope as this pitch is almost a full rope length.
content.location: This is the upper most climb in this section. The walk down to the anchors is fairly long, and gets steeper the closer you get to the top anchors. At the base of the climb there is a two bolt anchor about 15 feet climbers left that you can use to rappel down to Tennessee Stud.
